REFRACTION

When light passes two media, if the first medium is air and the second is water or glass, most of the light is transmitted into the second medium and bent towards the normal to the surface at the point of incidence. 

If the first medium is lighter. than the second, refraction is toward the normal. If the first is denser than the second it moves away from the normal.

Snell’s Laws of Reflection

  1. The incident ray, the refracted ray and the normal at the point of incidence all he lies on one plane
  2. If i is the angle of incidence and r angle of refraction

 constant (n), which is called absolute refraction index of the 2nd medium

Critical Angle

Consider light passing from dense to a rare medium. This entails refraction away from the normal

As the angle of incidence (i), is increased," the angle of refraction (r) also increases. At a certain angle of incidence. the refracted ray grazcs the interface. The angle of incidence at which this phenomenon occur is called Critical Angle (C) 

When the angles of incidence is greater than C, the beam is totally internally reflected. 

NB: Total internal reflected ray obeys the law of reflection. For the critical angle, the angle of refraction is 90°. 

 

n = 

Images in Converging Lens (Convex lens).

Master these, when the object is 

  1. At distance 2f from lens, image is real, inverted and same size as object
  2. Between 2f and f, image is real. inverted and bigger than object.
  3. Further than 2f, the image is ‘real, inverted and smaller than object
  4. Nearer than f, image is upright, magnified and virtual (magnifying glass)

Note in a Diverging lens (concave lens), the image is always virtual, upright(erect) and diminished.

Note also that converging lenses (convex lenses) are totally opposite to concave mirror. Reread their characteristics.

Example

A beam of light is incident from air to water at an angle of 30°. Find the angle of refraction if the refractive index of water is 4/3.

A. 15°, B. 18°, C. 22°, D. 240˚
